Award.AwardTitle: NSF/DOE Partnership on Advanced Combustion Engines: Thermal Barrier Coatings for the LTC Engine - Heat Loss, Combustion, Thermal vs. Catalytic Effects, Emissions, Exhaust Heat

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: This proposed research focuses on elucidating the impact of thermal barrier coatings (TBC) on the Low Temperature Combustion (LTC) engines, and designing an engineered coating that will produce the most desirable effects on combustion, efficiency, and emissions. Autoignition, combustion, and stability in an LTC engine critically depend on the interplay between the in-cylinder thermal environment and chemical kinetics. The impact of a thermal barrier on LTC engines was discovered recently but remains poorly understood. This effort will generate insight into mechanisms and magnitude of the effects. The research team will distinguish between the pure thermal and possible catalytic effects of coatings on thermo-kinetic processes in the cylinder, and quantify the improvement of engine thermal efficiency, LTC combustion efficiency, reduction of unburned hydrocarbons (UBHC), and CO emissions. The expected outcomes will remove some of the remaining obstacles to the practical implementation of LTC engines and reveal its impact on vehicle fuel economy. In addition to creating opportunities for PhD students, the research concepts from this project will be integrated into the courses in the Advanced Powertrain Track at Clemson University (CU), and incorporated in the unique MS program in Automotive Engineering that includes design and fabrication of a prototype vehicle. CU will also utilize outreach programs with a local elementary school and the Southern Automotive Women?s Forum to encourage young women and men to pursue STEM fields through immersion in hands-on demonstrations of advanced engine concepts. Additionally, the team will develop a workshop for the DaVinci Program of University of Connecticut (the collaborative institution), a flagship activity that trains inner city teachers in how science and math are applied to engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project elucidated the impact of thermal barrier coatings (TBC) on Low Temperature Combustion (LTC) engines, and guided development of engineered coatings capable of enhancing both combustion and thermal efficiencies, while reducing UBHC and CO emissions.  The findings increased the fundamental understanding of the underlying mechanisms responsible for the effects of coatings on LTC processes. 

The key outcome is confirmation of the hypothesis that a strategic manipulation of the combustion chamber surface temperature in an LTC engine can produce a tangible fuel efficiency benefit. In particular, a desired surface temperature swing during combustion is achieved with a thin coating of a low-conductivity ceramic material.  The low thermal mass of the layer allows temperatures to retreat to baseline values observed in a metal engine by the time of the subsequent intake event.  Our research confirmed that the overall benefit can be magnified by compounding the effect on combustion efficiency (due to enhanced reaction rates in the wall-affected zones) and the cycle thermal efficiency.

The simulation tools developed during this project identified the systematic reduction of TBC conductivity as the top priority for TBC development. Lowering a TBC’s conductivity was shown to increase the peak TBC surface temperature swing without inducing charge heating during the open portion of the engine cycle. Two avenues were attempted to accomplish this goal within the LTC engine. First, enclosed TBC porosity was systematically increased and organized into inter-pass boundary layers. This porosity network was subsequently sealed from the combustion gases with a dense top coat. While the inclusion of closed porosity decreased the effective coating conductivity, the resultant coatings were not structurally stable in the LTC engine.  Open pores and increased surface roughness led to undesirable fuel interactions.  Hence, excessive porosity should be avoided, and a preferred path is a denser coating made of a lower conductivity material.

The systematic study of the link between coating thermal properties and the LTC combustion/efficiency led to the design of a Gadolinium Zirconate coating, which exhibited gross indicated thermal efficiency improvements in range of 5.3% - 5.9% (2.1 to 2.4 absolute percentage points) relative to the metal baseline engine, and a 37% expansion of the HCCI operating range.  This exceeds the expectations set in the original proposal. 

In addition to educating PhD students, the research concepts from this project generated new units for courses at Clemson University.  The CU’s outreach programs with Dr. Phinnize J. Fisher Middle School and the Southern Automotive Women’s Forum, served to encourage young women and men to pursue STEM fields.  Two workshops on high-efficiency powertrains were developed for the UConn’s flagship DaVinci Program, which brought inner city High School and Middle School teachers to campus for a week intensive course in how science and math are applied to engineering.  The research outcomes will remove some of the remaining barriers to introduction of practical LTC engines, and enhance their positive impact on vehicle fuel economy and reduced CO2 emissions from transportation.
